title: Breast party ever! Woman who sacrificed boobs to beat cancer celebrates mastectomy in style
text:
News Breast party ever! Woman who sacrificed boobs to beat cancer celebrates mastectomy in style Sally Chapman, 29, got rid of her 'bad boobs' after discovering she was a carrier of the lethal gene that increases the chance of developing cancer Share Sally Chapman celebrated getting rid of her 'bad boobs' with a party (Photo: Caters News Agency) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A mastectomy patient waved goodbye to her old breasts and welcomed new ones by throwing a BOOB party. 
Sally Chapman, 29, from Hinckley, Leicestershire, discovered she was a carrier of the lethal gene BRCA that increases the chance of developing a fatal cancer in 2012. 
After recognising her family's cursed history of cancer-related deaths, with 11 of her grandmother's siblings all dying due to the disease, she opted for a double mastectomy two-years-ago. 
She held a ' Goodbye bad boobs ' party to bring up her spirit - eating boob shaped cake, playing pin the tassel on the breast and battling a boob-shaped pinata. 
The secondary-school teacher had breast and nipple reconstruction and to complete the journey had coloured-ink tattooing on her nipples this month. Read More Doctors vacuum out breast cancer tumour - while the patient is AWAKE Sally discovered she was a carrier of the lethal gene that increases the chance of developing cancer (Photo: Caters News Agency) 
Last week, she held a celebration to conclude the end of her battle with the deadly gene that can increase a woman's risk of breast or ovarian cancer by up to 85%. 
Sally said: "I feel very relieved and lucky, it's like I've been given a lifeline, it was definitely the right decision for me. 
"Before I never realised how much at risk I was, so having a double mastectomy meant I didn't have to worry about my breasts again. 
"The reconstruction was very emotional but I can't describe how important feeling like a woman is. 
"To have gone through this journey I believe ensuring you have everything as back to as normal as possible has helped this journey. 
"I was really nervous about having the tattooing part before, I wasn't sure I wanted to have it done, however I am so glad I did as this now makes me feel complete. 
"I thought I should celebrate the end of the journey as I celebrated the start by having a goodbye party for my bad boobs. 
"I felt better for having the celebrations, as for me I prefer to talk about problems and tell people. 
"My party ending this all was such a lovely feeling, being able to celebrate with everyone who has supported separately at some point along my journey was incredible." The 29-year-old had a double mastectomy (Photo: Caters News Agency) 
Sally admits that after being told she carried the BRCA2 gene she didn't appreciate the dangers she was at risk of and only after researching online the hard facts hit home. 
She added: "I didn't understand what doctors were telling me, what I was going through, I didn't know enough about the statistics and how high risk I was at. 
"It didn't feel like I had worry about it at first because I wasn't ill or a breast cancer patient and was quite young. 
"Because I was young I thought I would have ages to consider my options and didn't want to worry about it but having BRCA is very serious. 
"I was told by someone going through preventative surgery that 'You're only as young as you are today' which after a time helped me realise I needed to take action." 
Prior to having a double mastectomy with expanders in 2015, she threw a party to say 'goodbye' to the breasts that had the potential to kill her. Sally after her breast reconstruction (Photo: Caters News Agency) 
Sally said: "I had my goodbye bad boobs party a couple of weeks before my surgery with friends and family. 
"We had a boob cake, pin the tassels on the boobs and boob pinatas." 
After having both breasts and nipples removed she received saline injection into her expanders every three months, to stretch the skin ready for an implant. 
She had implants placed inside and later opted to have nipples constructed from the fat beneath the scar tissue in her breasts 
Sally said: "I didn't know what to expect, I was more on edge for that then any of the other surgeries, but I was surprised how lifelike my breasts looked. 
"After having the implants in I couldn't believe how real and how human they felt - it's made such a difference." Read More Single mum got flower tattoo to cover cancer surgery scars â€“ and fell in love with the artist Sally's party even featured a boob cake (Photo: Caters News Agency) 
Earlier this month she finished her journey after having specialist ink tattooing to the nipples and is now looking forward to a healthy future. 
Sally who started a blog to document her journey, is now applying for charity status to help other BRCA patients and encourage everyone to get tested for BRCA. 
She said: "I think everyone should have the option to be tested and there needs to be more awareness about it. 
"I've been holding events since November to educate people about BRCA and to spread awareness."
